{{Year box}} '''1847 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Baseball]]== '''Events''' * Army of occupation plays baseball in [[Santa Barbara, California]], alienating the local people.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090809204534/http://retrosheet.org/Protoball/chron.htm Protoball 1847.7]. Retrieved on 7 November 2009.</ref>
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * [[William Thompson (boxer)|William Thompson]] retains the Championship of England but there is no record of any fights involving him in 1847.<ref name="WT">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/thompson.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Bendigo]. Retrieved on 7 November 2009.</ref>
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * [[William Clarke's All-England Eleven]] (AEE), formed in 1846, becomes a major attraction and plays numerous matches throughout England '''England''' * Most runs – [[Nicholas Felix]] 591 @ 28.14 (HS 113) * Most wickets – [[William Hillyer]] 134 @ 16.15 (BB 8–?)
==[[Football]]== '''Events''' * Another set of public school rules is created at [[Harrow School|Harrow]] which, like [[Eton College|Eton]], plays the "dribbling game".
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1847 Grand National|Grand National]] – [[Mathew (horse)|Mathew]] * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Clementina * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Conyngham * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Cossack (horse)|Cossack]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Miami * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – Van Tromp
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * The [[Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]] is not held this year

{{undisclosed paid|date=July 2017}} {{Orphan|date=June 2014}}
{{Infobox company | name = BodyCode Training System | logo = File:BodyCode_Training_System.png | logo_caption = | image = | image_caption = | type = | industry = | founder = Pino Carbone | location_city = | location_country = | area_served = | key_people = | products = Exercise equipment, accessories, | services = | parent = | divisions = | homepage = {{URL|www.bodycodesystem.com}} | footnotes = | intl = | bodystyle = }} '''BodyCode Training System''' is a technique for evaluating and correcting movement patterns using specifically designed equipment. It deals with how people construct awkward postures, and how to maintain and apply intervention strategies to correct them. It was developed in the 1990s by Pino Carbone.<ref name=EE/> It is mainly used by dancers and athletes but can be used by anybody. It is among the curricula of [[Boston Ballet|Boston Ballet School]], the [[National Ballet of China|Chinese National Ballet]], [[English National Ballet School]], and other private ballet school.<ref name=TR/>
BodyCode Training System includes [[Aerobic exercise|aerobic]] and [[Anaerobic exercise|anaerobic activities]], [[Isometric exercise|isometric]] and [[Isotonic (exercise physiology)|isotonic exercises]] and proprioceptive movement, as well as static and dynamic activities.<ref name=EE/> The specific set of exercises suitable for an individual is designed by a trainer after a postural examination.<ref name=TV>{{cite web|url=http://www.telva.com/2008/05/27/estarbienfitness/1211878356.html|title= Body-Code|publisher=Telva|accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref> In 2004, Carbone was awarded Geneva’s international inventor’s prize for designing BodyCode equipment called SpheralMind.<ref name=TF/>
== History == BodyCode Training System was developed by Pino Carbone. Carbone was a professional dancer for several years before he had an accident in the 1980s during the rehearsal of a ballet that affected his back and resulted in a [[Spinal disc herniation|herniated disc]]. Following his injury, he had to incorporate acupuncture, Pilates, Gyrotonics [[yoga]], [[massage]] and [[physical therapy]] in his regimen in order to continue with his dancing. At that time, he started research to develop a training system for strengthening and stretching muscles without the risk of injury that he could use.<ref name=TR>{{cite web|url=http://mujer.terra.es/muj/articulo/html/mu225597.htm|title= Body Code: cuerpo y men| publisher=Terra|accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref> After several years of research and work, he developed the BodyCode System in the 1990s.<ref name=ABC>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.es/hemeroteca/historico-19-01-2008/abc/Sabados/%C2%A1a-moverse!-body-code-en-forma-sin-desgaste_1641570674316.html |title=¡A moverse! Body Code, en forma sin desgaste|publisher=ABC.es|accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref> According to Carbone, he was tired of dancing in pain. He wanted to settle down and open his own studio. By then he was already doing [[Gyrotonics]] with Juliu Horvath, in New York City, so he decided to open his first studio in [[Florence]] and offer training that combined principles of yoga, dance, Gyrotonics and [[Pilates]].<ref name=TF/>
Although Carbone primarily worked with dancers and athletes, in the early 1990s, he began collaborating with orthopaedics, neurosurgeons and other medical specialists.<ref name=PL/><ref name=RR>{{cite web|url=http://www.reportpistoia.com/archivio-benessere/6954-che-cosa-e-il-metodo-bodycode.html|title= Che cosa è il metodo Bodycode|publisher=Report Pistoia|accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref> Currently, it is taught in dance programs worldwide.<ref name=PL/>
== Principles == BodyCode exercises are based on the principles of harmonizing body and mind. The basis of the method is to restore the physical as well as mental balance. Theories of BodyCode have oriental roots and are related to [[acupuncture]], yoga, dance and [[feng shui]].<ref name=EL>{{cite web|url=http://www.elle.es/belleza/cara-cuerpo/en-forma-con-body-code|title=La nueva disciplina para poner a punto cuerpo y mente|publisher=Elle Spanish|accessdate=22 February 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140227175444/http://www.elle.es/belleza/cara-cuerpo/en-forma-con-body-code#|archive-date=2014-02-27|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> It draws influences from Gyrotonics as well as Pilates.<ref name=TF>{{cite web|url=http://www.theflorentine.net/articles/article-view.asp?issuetocId=1642|title= An Interview with Pino Carbone|publisher=The Florentine|accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref>
BodyCode also employs basic principles of traditional gymnastics and dance movements. The purpose of the method is to improve the body movement and postural alignment.<ref name=TR/><ref>{{cite news|publisher=Elle Spanish|title=El Codigo Da Pino|date=September 2008|pages=233, 234}}</ref> BodyCode Training System includes [[Aerobic exercise|aerobic]] and [[Anaerobic exercise|anaerobic activities]], [[Isometric exercise|isometric]] and [[Isotonic (exercise physiology)|isotonic exercises]] and proprioception exercises as well as static and dynamic activities.<ref name=EE/> It deals with how people construct awkward postures, and how to maintain and apply intervention strategies to correct them.<ref name=PL/>
== Approach and equipment == There are various pieces of equipment designed by Carbone for performing different body movements. Some of these are handmade<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vanitatis.com/cache/2008/09/18/tendencias_30_bodycode_fusion_entre_cuerpo_mente.html|title=BodyCode o la fusión entre cuerpo y mente|publisher=Vanitatis|accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref> and include ''Pegasus'', ''SpheralMind'', ''ProArch'', ''Geometrix'', ''Elvis'', ''Dance Ruler'' and ''MasterStretch''.<ref name=TV/> ''MasterStretch'' is developed for improving the flexibility of the spine and coordination and proprioception.<ref name=EE>{{cite web|url=http://ecodiario.eleconomista.es/evasion/gente-estilo/noticias/480996/04/08/Body-Code-la-manera-de-hacer-ejercicio-en-el-siglo-XXI.html |title=Body Code, la manera de hacer ejercicio en el siglo XXI|publisher=El Economista|accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref>
Carbone holds the trademark for BodyCode system as well as several equipment design patents. Only legally authorized instructors can lawfully provide BodyCode training. Before beginning BodyCode training, an individual's posture and balance are evaluated in order to determine their weaknesses and their requirements. Following this assessment, the instructor prepares a program that is focused on rebalancing the body.<ref name=ABC/> The first phase of evaluating body posture is called ''decoding'' and the second phase of training to improve balance is called ''coding''.<ref name=PL>{{cite news|publisher=Pilates Lifestyle|title=Body Talk – Cracking the Code of Movement|first=Heidi|last=Dvorak}}</ref>
=== Work in === BodyCode uses the concept of work-in as opposed to work-out. According to this concept, the physical imbalance, stress, trauma, bad habits and poor posture should not be corrected externally but internally. The individuals while practising this technique are taught to be aware of their body characteristics and how to train it.<ref name=PL/>
== In the media == The BodyCode System was featured in Marie Claire Spanish in the article ''Top ten en gimnasios - El más barato (Top ten cheapest gym equipment)''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marie-claire.es/belleza/cuerpo/fotos/fotos-gimansios-10/fotos-10-gimnasios-10___12219|title=Top ten en gimnasios - El más barato|publisher=Marie Claire|accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Gyrotonic]]
== References == {{reflist|2}}
== External links == {{official website|www.bodycodesystem.com}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox civilian attack | title = Borussia Dortmund team bus bombing | partof = | image = File:Anschlag auf den Mannschaftsbus von Borussia Dortmund 011.jpg | image_size = 250px | alt = | caption = The hedge damaged by the blasts | map = {{Location map| Germany North Rhine-Westphalia#Germany | width = 220 | label = Dortmund | float = center | background = #FFFFDD | coordinates = {{coord|51|26|59|N|7|30|22|E}} }} | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | location = [[Dortmund]], [[Germany]] | target = Borussia Dortmund team | coordinates = {{coord|51|26|59|N|7|30|22|E}} | date = {{Start date|df=yes|2017|04|11}} | time = 19:15<ref name="bvbannounce">{{Cite news|url=http://www.bvb.de/eng/content/view/full/135028|title="Targeted attack on the BVB Team Bus"|date=11 April 2017|work=Borussia Dortmund|access-date=15 April 2017}}</ref><ref name="dw">{{Cite news|url=http://www.dw.com/en/how-it-happened-explosion-hits-borussia-dortmund-bus-ahead-of-champions-league-game/a-38390378|title="How it happened: Explosion hits Borussia Dortmund bus ahead of Champions League game"|date=11 April 2017|work=Deutsche Welle|access-date=21 April 2017}}</ref> [[Central European Summer Time|CEST]] | timezone = [[UTC+2]] | type =Bombing | fatalities = 0 | injuries = 2 | susperp = Sergej W. | assailant = <!-- Do not add a name here until someone is convicted --> | weapons = 3 [[explosives]] | numparts = <!-- or | numpart = --> | dfens = <!-- or | dfen = --> | motive = [[Market manipulation]] | inquiry = | coroner = | accused = | convicted = | verdict = | convictions = | charges = | litigation = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | module = }} {{wikinews|Borussia Dortmund's team bus hit with explosives before Champions League match, Marc Bartra injured}} On 11 April 2017, the tour bus of German football team [[Borussia Dortmund]] was attacked with [[roadside bomb]]s in [[Dortmund]], Germany. Three bombs exploded as the bus ferried the team to the [[Westfalenstadion]] for the [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League knockout phase#Borussia Dortmund v Monaco|first leg of their quarter-final]] against [[AS Monaco FC|Monaco]] in the [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League|UEFA Champions League]]. One of the team's players, [[Marc Bartra]], and a policeman were wounded, but the strengthened windows of the bus prevented further casualties.
The initial line of inquiry assumed that it was an [[Islamic terrorism|Islamist terrorist]] attack due to letters found at the scene, which claimed the attack was an act of retaliation for Muslims killed in the [[German intervention against ISIL|German military intervention]] against [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|Islamic State]], and threatened further attacks unless Germany withdraws and the [[Ramstein Air Base|US military base in Ramstein]] is shut down. However, discrepancies in the evidence eventually led investigators to consider it a [[false flag]] attack. Additional claims of responsibility, supposedly from far-left and far-right groups, were also investigated.
On 21 April 2017, German police arrested a man on suspicion of planting bombs to drive down the Borussia Dortmund share price and profit by [[Warrant (finance)|put warrants]] he bought prior to the attack.<ref name="guardian-21apr">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/apr/21/dortmund-bus-attack-suspect-arrested-as-police-allege-share-dealing-plot|title=Dortmund attack: man arrested on suspicion of share-dealing plot|date=21 April 2017|work=The Guardian|access-date=21 April 2017|language=en-EN}}</ref>
==Bombing== The team bus of [[Borussia Dortmund]] was attacked with three homemade [[pipe bomb]]s while on its way to [[Westfalenstadion]] in [[Dortmund]]. The bombs were hidden in hedges by the roadside and detonated at around 19:15 [[Central_European_Summer_Time|local time]] (17:15 [[UTC]]).<ref name="bvbannounce"/><ref name="dw"/> They were packed with sharp metal pins and had a reach of about 100 meters (109 yards). Based on the type of detonator and explosive involved, German authorities assume "terrorist involvement".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/04/12/europe/dortmund-explosion-germany/index.html|title=Dortmund bus attack: 1 detained, 'terrorist involvement' suspected|website=CNN|access-date=12 April 2017|language=en}}</ref> The bombs used military detonators and the explosives may have come from military stocks.<ref>[http://www.dw.com/en/dortmund-attack-explosive-from-german-military-media/a-38439498 "Dortmund attack explosive 'from German military' - media"]. ''[[Die Welt]]''. 15 April 2017. Retrieved 17 April 2017.</ref> [[Spain|Spanish]] footballer and Dortmund's team member [[Marc Bartra]] was wounded by shards of glass from the shattered bus window; he was taken to a nearby hospital where his right wrist was immediately operated on.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.welt.de/sport/fussball/article163639356/Anschlag-in-Dortmund-Was-wir-wissen-was-nicht.html|title=Borussia Dortmund: Sprengstoffanschlag beim BVB – Was wir wissen, was nicht - WELT|website=DIE WELT|access-date=12 April 2017}}</ref> A policeman suffered blast injury and shock; he was escorting the bus on a motorcycle.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/panorama/justiz/borussia-dortmund-ein-verdaechtiger-nach-anschlag-festgenommen-a-1143065.html|title=Dortmund: Anschlag auf BVB-Bus - Ermittler nehmen Verdächtigen fest - SPIEGEL ONLINE - Panorama|last=Germany|first=SPIEGEL ONLINE, Hamburg|website=SPIEGEL ONLINE|access-date=12 April 2017}}</ref>
At the time, the bus was on its way to the first leg of Borussia Dortmund's [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League#Quarter-finals|2016–17 UEFA Champions League]] quarter-final against [[AS Monaco FC|Monaco]] at the [[Signal Iduna Park]]; the match was rescheduled for the following day.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.tagesspiegel.de/sport/explosionen-vor-champions-league-spiel-anschlag-auf-borussia-dortmund-gibt-ermittlern-raetsel-auf/19661954.html|title=Anschlag auf Borussia Dortmund gibt Ermittlern Rätsel auf|access-date=12 April 2017|language=de}}</ref>
[[File:Borussia Bus.jpg|thumb|none|left|The team bus of Borussia Dortmund in 2015]]
==Investigation== The German police and state lawyers are treating it as attempted murder and a planned attack on [[Borussia Dortmund]]. There were three claims of responsibility: one left at the scene claiming an Islamist motive, one posted on the internet claiming an 'anti-fascist' motive<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/panorama/justiz/borussia-dortmund-ermittler-pruefen-zwei-bekennerschreiben-a-1143004.html|title=Anschlag auf BVB-Bus: Ermittler prüfen zwei Bekennerschreiben - SPIEGEL ONLINE - Panorama|last=Germany|first=SPIEGEL ONLINE, Hamburg|website=SPIEGEL ONLINE|access-date=12 April 2017}}</ref> (which was deemed to be fake),<ref name=":3" /> and one later sent to a newspaper claiming a far-right motive. The German Federal Prosecutor's Office initially called the attack an act of terrorism with possible Islamist involvement.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/bvb-anschlag-in-dortmund-zwei-verdaechtige-eine-festnahme-1.3462381|title=Anschlag in Dortmund: Zwei Verdächtige, eine Festnahme|date=11 April 2017|work=sueddeutsche.de|access-date=12 April 2017|language=de|issn=0174-4917}}</ref> The Interior Minister of [[North Rhine-Westphalia]] called the attack "professional".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/politik/inland/keine-beweise-gegen-verdaechtigen-von-bvb-anschlag-gefunden-14970683.html|title=Anschlag auf Fußballmannschaft: NRW-Innenminister: Bomben auf BVB-Bus waren sehr professionell|date=13 April 2017|work=Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung|access-date=13 April 2017|language=de-DE|issn=0174-4909}}</ref> Police are investigating whether it was an attack by Islamists, by the far-left or by the far-right.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/panorama/justiz/dortmund-bombe-gegen-bvb-bus-laut-ralf-jaeger-professionell-gebaut-a-1143291.html|title=NRW-Innenminister Jäger über Anschlag in Dortmund: "Die Sprengkraft war enorm" - SPIEGEL ONLINE - Panorama|last=Germany|first=SPIEGEL ONLINE, Hamburg|website=SPIEGEL ONLINE|access-date=13 April 2017}}</ref> According to German media, investigators are also considering whether a foreign security service was behind the bombing.<ref>[http://www.dw.com/en/new-message-claims-responsibility-for-dortmund-blast/a-38433218 "New message claims responsibility for Dortmund blast"]. ''[[Die Welt]]''. 15 April 2017. Retrieved 17 April 2017.</ref>
===Claims of responsibility=== There were three differing claims of responsibility. The first claim was found in three identical letters left at the scene. The letters said the attack was retaliation for [[German intervention against ISIL|German military intervention]] against [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|Islamic State]] (ISIS) in [[Iraq]] and [[Syria]], accusing it of being responsible for killing Muslims. It demanded that the [[Ramstein Air Base|US military base in Ramstein]] be shut down and the German [[Panavia Tornado|Tornado jets]] be withdrawn from Syria. It threatened further attacks on non-Muslim celebrities in Germany unless the demands are met.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/apr/12/borussia-dortmund-blasts-police-investigate-islamist-link-to-attack|title=Borussia Dortmund blasts: suspect 'from Islamist spectrum' detained|last=Oltermann|first=Philip|date=12 April 2017|work=The Guardian|access-date=12 April 2017|last2=Connolly|first2=Kate|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> The letters were seen as unusual, as previous ISIS-linked attacks in Europe did not come with such confessions. Unlike previous video claims of responsibility, the letters directly addressed the German chancellor and had no religious justifications, ISIS logo, or signature.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/panorama/justiz/bvb-das-raetselhafte-bekennerschreiben-von-dortmund-a-1143121.html|title=Anschlag auf Mannschaftsbus: Das ungewöhnliche Bekennerschreiben von Dortmund - SPIEGEL ONLINE - Panorama|last=Germany|first=SPIEGEL ONLINE, Hamburg|website=SPIEGEL ONLINE|access-date=12 April 2017}}</ref> German newspapers later reported that investigators had "significant doubts" over the letters' authenticity, and suggested they may have been written to frame Islamists.<ref name=letters>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-39603467|title=Borussia Dortmund bombs: Letters at scene 'not from Islamists'|work=BBC News|date=14 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/borussia-dortmund-football-attack-explosion-terrorism-islam-extremism-doubts-frauke-koehler-a7684651.html|title=Major doubts about letters claiming Islamist motive for Dortmund attack|last=Mortimer|first=Caroline|publisher=The Independent|access-date=15 April 2017}}</ref>
Another claim was posted on the left-wing, open-publishing website [[IndyMedia]]. It said the attack was committed because Borussia Dortmund did not do enough against racists, Nazis, and right-wing populists within its fanbase.<ref name=":1" /> The claim was removed as fake, and police also treated it as fake.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://faktenfinder.tagesschau.de/bvb-fake-bekennerschreiben-101.html|title=Anschlag auf BVB: Ist Antifa-Bekennerschreiben ein Fake?|last=tagesschau.de|website=tagesschau.de|language=de-DE|access-date=12 April 2017}}</ref>
A few days later, a third claim of responsibility was sent to the newspaper ''[[Der Tagesspiegel]]'', which hinted at a far-right motive. The anonymous e-mail praised [[Adolf Hitler]] and attacked [[multiculturalism]], adding that the attack was a "last warning".<ref name=letters/><ref name=Independentprosecutors>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/dortmund-attack-bombing-borussia-team-bus-bvb-isis-terror-right-wing-extremists-claim-responsibility-a7685281.html|title=Prosecutors are investigating if Dortmund bombing could have been the work of right-wing extremists|date=15 April 2017|work=The Independent|access-date=15 April 2017|language=en-GB}}</ref> A spokeswoman for the federal prosecutors said the claim was being investigated.<ref name=Localprobe/> The letter also threatened another attack on protesters who plan to demonstrate against the [[Alternative for Germany]] party's conference in Cologne in 22 April.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/04/16/german-police-investigate-far-right-link-dortmund-bombing/|title=German police investigate far-Right link to Dortmund bombing|work=The Telegraph|access-date=19 April 2017|language=en-GB}}</ref> Police also considered the possibility that the attack was carried out by the [[Far-right politics in Germany|far-right]] in order to incite backlash against Muslims.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Pancevski|first1=Bojan|title=Dortmund attackers wanted to incite backlash against Muslims|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/66a34b32-21e6-11e7-84e8-86f619ed3761|website=The Times|accessdate=19 April 2017|date=16 April 2017}}</ref>
===Suspects=== {{wikinews|28-year-old suspect charged for attacking Borussia Dortmund's team bus}} In the initial stage of the investigation, the police identified two suspects and arrested one of them. The apartments of both suspects were searched.<ref name=":2" /> The arrested suspect was an [[Iraq]]i immigrant living in [[Wuppertal]] and was suspected of being an Islamist extremist.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.zeit.de/gesellschaft/2017-04/anschlag-bvb-bus-dortmund-live|title=Anschlag auf BVB-Bus: Ein verdächtiger Islamist festgenommen|last=Gaul|first=Simone|date=12 April 2017|work=Die Zeit|access-date=12 April 2017|last2=Breitinger|first2=Matthias|issn=0044-2070|last3=Beyer|first3=Tim|last4=Fritsch|first4=Oliver}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/politik/inland/anschlag-auf-bvb-bus-polizei-nimmt-einen-verdaechtigen-fest-14969298.html|title=Nach Anschlag auf BVB-Bus: Festgenommener Tatverdächtiger soll Iraker aus Wuppertal sein|date=12 April 2017|work=Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung|access-date=12 April 2017|language=de-DE|issn=0174-4909}}</ref> Police believe he led an ISIS unit in [[Iraq]] involved in killings, kidnappings, smuggling, and extortion.<ref name="ind1304">{{Cite news|title=Borussia Dortmund: German police call bombing suspect 'Isis member' as they issue arrest warrant|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/borussia-dortmund-latest-suspect-isis-member-germany-police-charge-bombing-bus-nails-football-team-a7681506.html|work=The Independent|date=13 April 2017}}</ref><ref name="tel1304">{{Cite news|title= 'Isil terrorist' suspect held in connection with Borussia Dortmund bombing |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/04/13/borussia-dortmund-blastsgerman-prosecutors-say-no-evidence-sole/|work=The Telegraph|date=13 April 2017}}</ref> However, police later concluded he was not responsible for the Dortmund bombing.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/panorama/justiz/dortmund-haftbefehl-gegen-verdaechtigen-nach-bvb-anschlag-beantragt-a-1143219.html|title=Nach Anschlag in Dortmund: Haftbefehl gegen Verdächtigen erlassen - SPIEGEL ONLINE - Panorama|last=Germany|first=SPIEGEL ONLINE, Hamburg|website=SPIEGEL ONLINE|access-date=13 April 2017}}</ref><ref name=Localprobe>{{cite news|title=Germany probes new message claiming Dortmund attack|url=https://www.thelocal.de/20170415/germany-probes-new-letter-claiming-dortmund-attack|work=Agence-France Presse|date=15 April 2017}}</ref>
On 21 April 2017, the federal prosecutor announced that it had arrested a 28-year-old German-Russian citizen, identified only as Sergej W., on suspicion of 20-fold attempted murder, bringing about an illegal detonation of explosives, and aggravated battery. The man had been staying at the Borussia team hotel. He planted explosives along the road where the team bus would later leave to the stadium. During check-in, he chose a room with a window facing the road so he would be able to remotely trigger the explosion when the bus passed by. It was revealed that on the day of the attack, he had bought [[Warrant (finance)|put warrants]] for €78,000 from an investment bank using the internet connection in his hotel room. These would have made him a large profit of up to €3.9 million if Dortmund's share price were to plummet after a successful attack, but it only dropped by 5% after the attack and later recovered. The unusual transaction raised suspicion of [[money laundering]] with bank employees, prompting them to alert authorities and pass to them the identity of Sergej W., which led to his arrest. Police also said Sergej W. left letters at the scene of the crime to frame Muslims for the attack.<ref name="guardian-21apr" />
==Aftermath== The match was postponed until the following day at 18:45 [[Central European Summer Time|local time]] (16:45 UTC), which resulted in a 3–2 win for Monaco.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.uefa.org/about-uefa/news/newsid=2457177.html|title=UEFA statement on Dortmund incident|date=11 April 2017|work=UEFA|access-date=15 April 2017}}</ref><ref name=":0" /> Both Monaco and Dortmund fans united in friendship after the bombing. Many Dortmund fans, Germans and local hotels offered Monaco fans free food and places to stay for the night.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com.au/2017/04/11/german-football-fans-show-french-rivals-amazing-hospitality-afte_a_22036056/|title=German Football Fans Show French Rivals Amazing Hospitality After Borussia Dortmund Bus Explosion|last=Sharwood|first=Anthony|date=12 April 2017|work=Huffington Post|access-date=12 April 2017|language=en-AU}}</ref> Chancellor of Germany [[Angela Merkel]] expressed her appalled reaction to the attack.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.zeit.de/gesellschaft/2017-04/borussia-dortmund-explosion-reaktionen-sport-politik|title=Explosion in Dortmund: Bestürzung und Anteilnahme für den BVB|date=12 April 2017|work=Die Zeit|access-date=12 April 2017|issn=0044-2070}}</ref> The staff of Borussia Dortmund and former football player [[Lothar Matthäus]] criticized the short-term planning of [[UEFA]].<ref name="NTV"> [http://www.n-tv.de/sport/fussball/Tuchel-und-Matthaeus-kritisieren-Uefa-hart-article19792197.html%7Ctitle=Tuchel Tuchel und Matthäus kritisieren Uefa hart]; released on 12 April 2017; NTV</ref>

{{About|the film}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Use British English|date=September 2012}} {{Infobox film | image = Chariots_of_fire.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Hugh Hudson]] | producer = [[David Puttnam]] | writer = [[Colin Welland]] | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Ben Cross]] * [[Ian Charleson]] * [[Nigel Havers]] * [[Cheryl Campbell]] * [[Alice Krige]] * [[Lindsay Anderson]] * [[Dennis Christopher]] * [[Nigel Davenport]] * [[Brad Davis (actor)|Brad Davis]] * [[Peter Egan]] * [[John Gielgud|Sir John Gielgud]] * [[Ian Holm]] * [[Patrick Magee (actor)|Patrick Magee]] }} | music = [[Vangelis]] | cinematography = [[David Watkin (cinematographer)|David Watkin]] | editing = [[Terry Rawlings]] | studio = [[Allied Stars Ltd]]
[[Goldcrest Films]]
Enigma Productions
[[The Ladd Company]] | distributor = [[Warner Bros.]]
{{small| (USA & Canada)}}
[[20th Century Fox]]
{{small| (International)}} | released = {{Film date|df=y|1981|3|30|Royal Command Film Performance|1981|5|15|United Kingdom}} | runtime = 124 minutes | country = United Kingdom | language = English | budget = $5.5 million (£3 million)Alexander Walker, ''Icons in the Fire: The Rise and Fall of Practically Everyone in the British Film Industry 1984-2000'', Orion Books, 2005 p28 | gross = $59 million (U.S.)[http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=chariotsoffire.htm ''Chariots of Fire''] at [[Box Office Mojo]] }} '''''Chariots of Fire''''' is a 1981 British [[historical period drama|historical drama film]]. It tells the fact-based story of two athletes in the [[1924 Summer Olympics|1924 Olympics]]: [[Eric Liddell]], a devout Scottish Christian who runs for the glory of God, and [[Harold Abrahams]], an English Jew who runs to overcome prejudice. The film was conceived and produced by [[David Puttnam]], written by [[Colin Welland]], and directed by [[Hugh Hudson]]. [[Ben Cross]] and [[Ian Charleson]] starred as Abrahams and Liddell, alongside [[Nigel Havers]], [[Ian Holm]], [[Lindsay Anderson]], [[John Gielgud]], [[Cheryl Campbell]], and [[Alice Krige]] in supporting roles. It was nominated for seven [[Academy Awards]] and won four, including [[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]] and [[Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay|Best Original Screenplay]]. It is ranked 19th in the [[British Film Institute]]'s list of [[BFI Top 100 British films|Top 100 British films]]. The film is also notable for its memorable [[Chariots of Fire (album)|electronic theme tune]] by [[Vangelis]], who won the [[Academy Award for Best Original Score]]. The film's title was inspired by the line, "Bring me my chariot of fire," from the [[William Blake]] poem adapted into the popular British hymn [[And did those feet in ancient time|"Jerusalem"]]; the hymn is heard at the end of the film.Dans, Peter E. [https://books.google.com/books?id=52GpN0Hzxd8C&pg=PA222&dq=colin+welland+jerusalem+%22chariots+of+fire%22&hl=en&ei=3EdJTPqqKovSsAP97PFI&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=colin%20welland%20jerusalem%20%22chariots%20of%20fire%22&f=false ''Christians in the Movies: A Century of Saints and Sinners''.] Rowman & Littlefield, 2009. p. 223. The original phrase "chariot(s) of fire" is from [[Books of Kings|2 Kings]] [[wikisource:Bible (King James)/2 Kings#2:11|2:11]] and [[wikisource:Bible (King James)/2 Kings#6:17|6:17]] in the Bible. ==Plot== In 1919, [[Harold Abrahams]] ([[Ben Cross]]) enters the [[University of Cambridge]], where he experiences [[anti-Semitism]] from the staff, but enjoys participating in the [[Gilbert and Sullivan]] club. He becomes the first person to ever complete the [[Trinity Great Court#The Great Court Run|Trinity Great Court Run]], running around the college courtyard in the time it takes for the clock to strike 12, and achieves an undefeated string of victories in various national running competitions. Although focused on his running, he falls in love with a leading Gilbert and Sullivan soprano, Sybil ([[Alice Krige]]). [[Eric Liddell]] ([[Ian Charleson]]), born in China of Scottish missionary parents, is in Scotland. His devout sister Jennie ([[Cheryl Campbell]]) disapproves of Liddell's plans to pursue competitive running, but Liddell sees running as a way of glorifying God before returning to China to work as a missionary. When they first race against each other, Liddell beats Abrahams. Abrahams takes it poorly, but [[Sam Mussabini]] ([[Ian Holm]]), a professional trainer whom he had approached earlier, offers to take him on to improve his technique. This attracts criticism from the Cambridge college masters ([[John Gielgud]] and [[Lindsay Anderson]]), who allege it is not gentlemanly for an amateur to "play the tradesman" by employing a professional coach. Abrahams dismisses this concern, interpreting it as cover for anti-Semitic and class-based prejudice. When Eric Liddell accidentally misses a church prayer meeting because of his running, his sister Jennie upbraids him and accuses him of no longer caring about God. Eric tells her that though he intends to eventually return to the China mission, he feels divinely inspired when running, and that not to run would be to dishonour God, saying, "I believe that God made me for a purpose. But He also made me fast, and when I run, I feel His pleasure." The two athletes, after years of training and racing, are accepted to represent Great Britain in the [[1924 Summer Olympics|1924 Olympics]] in Paris. Also accepted are Abrahams' Cambridge friends, Lord Andrew Lindsay ([[Nigel Havers]]), [[Aubrey Montague]] ([[Nicholas Farrell]]), and [[H. B. Stallard|Henry Stallard]] ([[Daniel Gerroll]]). While boarding the boat to Paris for the Olympics, Liddell discovers the heats for his 100-metre race will be on a Sunday. He refuses to run the race, despite strong pressure from the [[Edward VIII of the United Kingdom|Prince of Wales]] and the British Olympic committee, because his Christian convictions prevent him from running on the [[Sabbath in Christianity|Sabbath]]. Hope appears when Liddell's teammate Lindsay, having already won a silver medal in the [[400 metres hurdles]], proposes to concede his place in the [[400 metres|400-metre race]] on the following Thursday to Liddell, who gratefully agrees. His religious convictions in the face of national athletic pride make headlines around the world. Liddell delivers a sermon at the Paris [[Church of Scotland]] that Sunday, and quotes from [[wikisource:Bible (King James)/Isaiah#Chapter 40|Isaiah 40]], ending with, "But they that wait upon the Lord shall renew their strength; they shall mount up with wings as eagles; they shall run, and not be weary; and they shall walk, and not faint." Abrahams is badly beaten by the heavily favoured United States runners in the 200 metre race. He knows his last chance for a medal will be the 100 metres. He competes in the race, and wins. His coach Sam Mussabini is overcome that the years of dedication and training have paid off with an Olympic gold medal. Now Abrahams can get on with his life and reunite with his girlfriend Sybil, whom he had neglected for the sake of running. Before Liddell's race, the American coach remarks dismissively to his runners that Liddell has little chance of doing well in his now far longer 400 metre race. But one of the American runners, [[Jackson Scholz]], hands Liddell a note of support for his convictions. Liddell defeats the American favourites and wins the gold medal. The British team returns home triumphant. As the film ends, onscreen text explains that Abrahams married Sybil, and became the elder statesman of British athletics. Liddell went on to missionary work in China. All of Scotland mourned his death in 1945 in Japanese-occupied China. == Cast {{anchor|Main cast}} == * [[Ben Cross]] as [[Harold Abrahams]], a Jewish student at Cambridge University * [[Ian Charleson]] as [[Eric Liddell]], the son of Scottish missionaries to China * [[Nicholas Farrell]] as [[Aubrey Montague]], a runner and friend of Harold Abrahams * [[Nigel Havers]] as Lord Andrew Lindsay, a Cambridge student runner partially based on [[David Cecil, 6th Marquess of Exeter|David Burghley]] and [[Douglas Lowe (athlete)|Douglas Lowe]] * [[Ian Holm]] as [[Sam Mussabini]], Abrahams's running coach * [[John Gielgud]] as Master of [[Trinity College, Cambridge|Trinity College]] at Cambridge University * [[Lindsay Anderson]] as Master of [[Caius College]] at Cambridge University * [[Cheryl Campbell]] as Jennie Liddell, Eric's devout sister (Janet Lillian "Jenny" Liddell) * [[Alice Krige]] as [[Sybil Gordon]], Abrahams' fiancée (his actual fiancée was [[Sybil Evers]]) * [[Struan Rodger]] as Sandy McGrath, Liddell's friend and running coach * [[Nigel Davenport]] as [[F. E. Smith, 1st Earl of Birkenhead|Lord Birkenhead]], member of the [[British Olympic Association|British Olympic Committee]], who counsels the athletes * [[Patrick Magee (actor)|Patrick Magee]] as [[Gerald Cadogan, 6th Earl Cadogan|Lord Cadogan]], chairman of the British Olympics Committee, who is unsympathetic to Liddell's religious plight * [[David Yelland (actor)|David Yelland]] as the [[Edward VIII of the United Kingdom|Prince of Wales]], who tries to get Liddell to change his mind about running on Sunday * [[Peter Egan]] as the [[George Sutherland-Leveson-Gower, 5th Duke of Sutherland|Duke of Sutherland]], president of the British Olympic Committee, who is sympathetic to Liddell * [[Daniel Gerroll]] as [[H. B. Stallard|Henry Stallard]], a Cambridge student and runner * [[Dennis Christopher]] as [[Charley Paddock]], American Olympic runner * [[Brad Davis (actor)|Brad Davis]] as [[Jackson Scholz]], American Olympic runner * [[Richard Griffiths]] as the Head Porter at Caius College == Historical accuracy == === Characters === The film depicts Abrahams as attending [[Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge]] with three other Olympic athletes: [[H. B. Stallard|Henry Stallard]], [[Aubrey Montague]], and Lord Andrew Lindsay. Abrahams and Stallard were in fact students there and competed in the 1924 Olympics. Montague also competed in the Olympics as depicted, but he attended Oxford, not Cambridge.[https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/mo/evelyn-montague-1.html Aubrey Montague biography] at SportsReference.com Aubrey Montague sent daily letters to his mother about his time at Oxford and the Olympics; these letters were the basis of Montague's narration in the film. The character of Lindsay was based partially on [[David Cecil, 6th Marquess of Exeter|Lord Burghley]], a significant figure in the history of British athletics. Although Burghley did attend Cambridge, he was not a contemporary of Harold Abrahams, as Abrahams was an undergraduate from 1919 to 1923 and Burghley was at Cambridge from 1923 to 1927. One scene in the film depicts the Burghley-based "Lindsay" as practising hurdles on his estate with full champagne glasses placed on each hurdle – this was something the wealthy Burghley did, although he used matchboxes instead of champagne glasses. The fictional character of Lindsay was created when [[Douglas Lowe (athlete)|Douglas Lowe]], who was Britain's third athletics gold medallist in the 1924 Olympics, was not willing to be involved with the film.Chapman, pp. 275, 295. [[File:Cross and Havers.jpg|thumb|right|230px|[[Harold Abrahams|Abrahams]] (left) and the [[David Cecil, 6th Marquess of Exeter|Burghley]]-based Lindsay (right) attempt the [[Trinity Great Court#The Great Court Run|Great Court Run]].]] Another scene in the film recreates the [[Trinity Great Court#The Great Court Run|Great Court Run]], in which the runners attempt to run around the perimeter of the [[Trinity Great Court|Great Court]] at [[Trinity College, Cambridge]] in the time it takes the clock to strike 12 at midday. The film shows Abrahams performing the feat for the first time in history. In fact, Abrahams never attempted this race, and at the time of filming the only person on record known to have succeeded was [[David Cecil, 6th Marquess of Exeter|Lord Burghley]], in 1927. In ''Chariots of Fire'', Lindsay, who is based on Lord Burghley, runs the Great Court Run with Abrahams in order to spur him on, and crosses the finish line just a moment too late. Since the film's release, the Great Court Run has also been successfully run by Trinity undergraduate Sam Dobin, in October 2007.[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-490027/Modern-day-hero-runs-away-Chariots-Fire-challenge.html "Modern-day hero runs away with Chariots of Fire challenge."] ''[[Daily Mail]]'' 27 October 2007. In the film, Eric Liddell is tripped up by a Frenchman in the 400-metre event of a Scotland–France international athletic meeting. He recovers, makes up a 20-metre deficit, and wins. This was based on fact; the actual race was the 440 yards at a Triangular Contest meet between Scotland, England, and Ireland at [[Stoke-on-Trent]] in England in July 1923. His achievement was remarkable as he had already won the 100- and 220-yard events that day.{{cite book|last=Ramsey|first=Russell W.|title=God's Joyful Runner|publisher=Bridge Publishing, Inc|year=1987|page=54|isbn=0-88270-624-1}} Also unmentioned with regard to Liddell is that it was he who introduced Abrahams to [[Sam Mussabini]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/scotland/sportscotland/asportingnation/article/0019/ |title=A Sporting Nation: Eric Liddell |publisher=BBC.co.uk|accessdate=13 March 2012}} This is alluded to: In the film Abrahams first encounters Mussabini while he is watching Liddell race. The film, however, suggests that Abrahams himself sought Mussabini's assistance. Abrahams and Liddell did race against each other once, but not quite as depicted in the film, which shows Liddell winning the final of the 100 yards against a shattered Abrahams at the 1923 AAA Championship at Stamford Bridge. In fact, they raced only in a heat of the 220 yards, which Liddell won, five yards ahead of Abrahams, who did not progress to the final. In the 100 yards, Abrahams was eliminated in the heats and never raced against Liddell, who won the finals of both races the next day.{{cite book|last=McCasland|first=David|title=Pure Gold: A New Biography of the Olympic Champion Who Inspired Chariots of Fire|publisher=Discovery House|year=2001|isbn=1572931302}} Abrahams' fiancée is misidentified as [[Sybil Gordon]], a soprano at the [[D'Oyly Carte Opera Company]]. In fact, in 1936, Abrahams married [[Sybil Evers]], who sang at the D'Oyly Carte, but they did not meet until 1934.Ryan (2012), p. 188. Also, in the film, Sybil is depicted as singing the role of Yum-Yum in ''[[The Mikado]]'', but neither Sybil Gordon nor Sybil Evers ever sang that role with D'Oyly Carte,Stone, David. [http://math.boisestate.edu/gas/whowaswho/G/GordonSybil.htm Sybil Gordon] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091001194722/http://math.boisestate.edu/gas///whowaswho/G/GordonSybil.htm# |date=1 October 2009 }} at the ''Who Was Who in the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company'' website, 11 July 2002. Retrieved 8 November 2009Stone, David. [http://diamond.boisestate.edu/gas/whowaswho/E/EversSybil.htm Sybil Evers] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141015040156/http://diamond.boisestate.edu/gas/whowaswho/E/EversSybil.htm# |date=15 October 2014 }} at the ''Who Was Who in the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company'' website, 28 January 2002. Retrieved 8 November 2009 although Evers was known for her charm in singing Peep-Bo, one of the two other "little maids from school". Harold Abrahams' love of and heavy involvement with [[Gilbert and Sullivan]], as depicted in the film, is factual.Hugh Hudson's commentary to the 2005 ''Chariots of Fire'' DVD Liddell's sister was several years younger than she was portrayed in the film. Her disapproval of Liddell's track career was creative licence; she actually fully supported his sporting work. Jenny Liddell Somerville cooperated fully with the making of the film and has a brief cameo in the Paris [[Church of Scotland]] during Liddell's sermon.Ramsey, Russell W. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=2AGEFpEByIoC&pg=PP4&dq=eric+liddell+jenny&num=100&cd=4# A Lady – A Peacemaker]''. Boston: Branden Publishing Company, 1988. At the memorial service for Harold Abrahams, which opens the film, Lord Lindsay mentions that he and [[Aubrey Montague]] are the only members of the 1924 Olympic team still alive. However, Montague died in 1948, 30 years before Abrahams' death. ===1924 Olympics=== {{See also|Great Britain at the 1924 Summer Olympics}} The film takes some liberties with the events at the 1924 Olympics, including the events surrounding Liddell's refusal to race on a Sunday. In the film, he doesn't learn that the 100-metre heat is to be held on the Christian Sabbath until he is boarding the boat to Paris. In fact, the schedule was made public several months in advance; Liddell did however face immense pressure to run on that Sunday and to compete in the 100 metres, getting called before a grilling by the British Olympic Committee, the Prince of Wales, and other [[grandee]]s, and his refusal to run made headlines around the world.Murray, Feg. [https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/361517352.html?dids=361517352:361517352&FMT=CITE&FMTS=CITE:AI&type=historic&date=Jun+24%2C+1924&author=&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=DID+YOU+KNOW+THAT--&pqatl=google "DID YOU KNOW THAT ..."]. ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''. 24 June 1924. Full headline reads, "Did You Know That Famous Scotch Sprinter Will Not Run in the Olympic 100 Metres Because The Trials Are Run on Sunday". The decision to change races was, even so, made well before embarking to Paris, and Liddell spent the intervening months training for the 400 metres, an event in which he had previously excelled. It is true, nonetheless, that Liddell's success in the Olympic 400m was largely unexpected. The film depicts Lindsay, having already won a medal in the 400-metre hurdles, giving up his place in the 400-metre race for Liddell. In fact [[David Burghley|Burghley]], on whom Lindsay is loosely based, was eliminated in the heats of the 110 hurdles (he would go on to win a gold medal in the 400 hurdles at the 1928 Olympics), and was not entered for the 400 metres. The film reverses the order of Abrahams' 100m and 200m races at the Olympics. In reality, after winning the 100 metres race, Abrahams ran the [[200 metres]] but finished last, [[Jackson Scholz]] taking the gold medal. In the film, before his triumph in the 100m, Abrahams is shown losing the 200m and being scolded by Mussabini. And during the following scene in which Abrahams speaks with his friend Montague while receiving a massage from Mussabini, there is a French newspaper clipping showing Scholz and [[Charlie Paddock]] with a headline which states that the 200 metres was a triumph for the United States. In the same conversation, Abrahams laments getting "beaten out of sight" in the 200. The film thus has Abrahams overcoming the disappointment of losing the 200 by going on to win the 100, a reversal of the real order. Eric Liddell actually also ran in the 200m race, and finished third, behind Paddock and Scholz. This was the only time in reality that Liddell and Abrahams competed in the same race. While their meeting in the 1923 [[Amateur Athletic Association|AAA]] Championship in the film was fictitious, Liddell's record win in that race did spur Abrahams to train even harder.{{cite web|url=http://content.ericliddell.org/ericliddell/recollections/content/arthurmarshall.htm |title=Recollections by Sir Arthur Marshall |publisher=Content.ericliddell.org |date= |accessdate=28 April 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090215092135/http://content.ericliddell.org/ericliddell/recollections/content/arthurmarshall.htm |archivedate=15 February 2009 }} Abrahams also won a silver medal as an opening runner for the [[4 x 100 metres relay]] team, not shown in the film, and [[Aubrey Montague]] placed sixth in the [[steeplechase (athletics)|steeplechase]], as depicted. ====Personal inaccuracies at the Olympics==== In the film, the 100m bronze medallist is a character called "Tom Watson"; the real medallist was [[Arthur Porritt, Baron Porritt|Arthur Porritt]] of New Zealand, who refused permission for his name to be used in the film, allegedly out of modesty, and his wish was accepted by the film's producers, even though his permission was not necessary.{{cite web|author=Arthur Espie Porritt 1900–1994 |url=http://www.library.otago.ac.nz/exhibitions/rhodes_scholars/arthur_espie_porritt.html |title=Reference to Porritt's modesty |publisher=Library.otago.ac.nz |date= |accessdate=28 April 2009}} However, the brief back-story given for Watson, who is called up to the New Zealand team from the [[University of Oxford]], substantially matches Porritt's history. With the exception of Porritt, all the runners in the 100m final are identified correctly when they line up for inspection by the Prince of Wales. Jackson Scholz is depicted as handing Liddell an inspirational Bible-quotation message before the 400 metres final: "It says in the Old Book, 'He that honors me, I will honor.' Good luck."The quoted passage is [[Books of Samuel|First Samuel]] [[wikisource:Bible (King James)/1 Samuel#2:30|2:30]]. In reality, the note was from members of the British team, and was handed to Liddell before the race by his attending masseur at the team's Paris hotel.Reid, Alasdair. "Harold Abrahams and Eric Liddell". ''[[The Times]]''. 1 August 2000. For dramatic purposes, screenwriter Welland asked Scholz if he could be depicted handing the note, and Scholz readily agreed, saying "Yes, great, as long as it makes me look good."{{cite journal | title = Britain's 1924 Olympic Champs Live Again in 'Chariots of Fire'—and Run Away with the Oscars | work = [[People (American magazine)|People]] | date =10 May 1982 | volume = 17 | issue = 18 | url = http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20082112,00.html | accessdate =22 August 2009}} == Production == === Script and direction === [[File:Charleson as Liddell.jpg|thumb|[[Ian Charleson]], who studied the Bible intensively for his role, wrote Eric Liddell's post-race inspirational speech to a working-class crowd.]] Producer [[David Puttnam]] was looking for a story in the mold of ''[[A Man for All Seasons (1966 film)|A Man for All Seasons]]'' (1966), regarding someone who follows his conscience, and felt sports provided clear situations in this sense.Goodell, Gregory. [https://books.google.com/books?id=T1kc5_QjiF4C&pg=PR17&lpg=PR17&dq=%22david+puttnam%22+%22chariots+of+fire%22+%22man+for+all+seasons%22&source=bl&ots=LvE2kYmoFg&sig=gmauWSjGfpFMK2WqFSkEdz5GmrM&hl=en&ei=zdEPS7jiM8KInQfgrOT0DA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=22&ved=0CEMQ6AEwFQ#v=onepage&q=%22david%20puttnam%22%20%22chariots%20of%20fire%22%20%22man%20for%20all%20seasons%22&f=false ''Independent Feature Film Production: A Complete Guide from Concept Through Distribution.''] New York: St. Martin's Press, 1982. p. xvii. He discovered Eric Liddell's story by accident in 1977, when he happened upon a reference book on the Olympics while housebound from the flu in a rented house in Los Angeles.Nichols, Peter M. [https://books.google.com/books?id=FIydEd00DbcC&pg=PA59&lpg=PA59&dq=%22david+puttnam%22+%22chariots+of+fire%22+olympics+book+rented+house&source=bl&ots=SwOUBnTU_L&sig=iY-8ny3tRtAkR14raOQLrQIZDSA&hl=en&ei=TtYPS46PBNXMngenuajTAw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CCAQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=%22david%20puttnam%22%20%22chariots%20of%20fire%22%20olympics%20book%20rented%20house&f=false ''The New York Times Essential Library, Children's Movies: A Critic's Guide to the Best Films Available on Video and DVD''.] New York: Times Books, 2003. p. 59.Hugh Hudson in ''Chariots of Fire – The Reunion'' (2005 video; featurette on 2005 ''Chariots of Fire'' DVD) Screenwriter [[Colin Welland]], commissioned by Puttnam, did an enormous amount of research for his [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]]-winning script. Among other things, he took out advertisements in London newspapers seeking memories of the 1924 Olympics, went to the National Film Archives for pictures and footage of the 1924 Olympics, and interviewed everyone involved who was still alive. Welland just missed Abrahams, who died 14 January 1978, but he did attend Abrahams' February 1978 memorial service, which inspired the present-day framing device of the film. [[Aubrey Montague]]'s son saw Welland's newspaper ad and sent him copies of the letters his father had sent home – which gave Welland something to use as a narrative bridge in the film. Except for changes in the greetings of the letters from "Darling Mummy" to "Dear Mum" and the change from Oxford to Cambridge, all of the readings from Montague's letters are from the originals. Welland's original script also featured, in addition to Eric Liddell and Harold Abrahams, a third protagonist, 1924 Olympic gold medallist [[Douglas Lowe (athlete)|Douglas Lowe]], who was presented as a privileged aristocratic athlete. However, Lowe refused to have anything to do with the film, and his character was written out and replaced by the fictional character of Lord Andrew Lindsay.Chapman, pp. 274–295. [[Ian Charleson]] himself wrote Eric Liddell's speech to the post-race workingmen's crowd at the Scotland v. Ireland races. Charleson, who had studied the Bible intensively in preparation for the role, told director Hugh Hudson that he didn't feel the portentous and sanctimonious scripted speech was either authentic or inspiring. Hudson and Welland allowed him to write words he personally found inspirational instead.Ian McKellen, Hugh Hudson, Alan Bates, et al. [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0094702500 ''For Ian Charleson: A Tribute'']. London: Constable and Company, 1990. pp. 37–39. {{ISBN|0-09-470250-0}} The film was slightly altered for the U.S. audience. A brief scene depicting a pre-Olympics [[cricket]] game between Abrahams, Liddell, Montague, and the rest of the British track team appears shortly after the beginning of the original film. For the American audience, this brief scene was deleted. In the U.S., to avoid the initial G rating, which had been strongly associated with children's films and might have hindered box office sales, a different scene was used – one depicting Abrahams and Montague arriving at a Cambridge railway station and encountering two [[World War I]] veterans who use an [[shit|obscenity]] – in order to be given a [[Motion Picture Association of America film rating system|PG rating]].Puttnam interviewed in BBC Radio obituary of [[Jack Valenti]]. Puttnam chose [[Hugh Hudson]], a multiple award-winning advertising and documentary filmmaker who had never helmed a feature film, to direct ''Chariots of Fire''. Hudson and Puttnam had known each other since the 1960s, when Puttnam was an advertising executive and Hudson was making films for ad agencies. In 1977, Hudson had also been [[second-unit]] director on the Puttnam-produced film ''[[Midnight Express (film)|Midnight Express]]''.Round, Simon. [http://www.thejc.com/lifestyle/the-simon-round-interview/58023/interview-hugh-hudson "Interview: Hugh Hudson"]. ''[[The Jewish Chronicle]]''. 10 November 2011. ===Casting=== Director [[Hugh Hudson]] was determined to cast young, unknown actors in all the major roles of the film, and to back them up by using veterans like [[John Gielgud]], [[Lindsay Anderson]], and [[Ian Holm]] as their supporting cast. Hudson and producer [[David Puttnam]] did months of fruitless searching for the perfect actor to play Eric Liddell. They then saw Scottish stage actor [[Ian Charleson]] performing the role of Pierre in the [[Royal Shakespeare Company]]'s production of ''[[Piaf (play)|Piaf]]'', and knew immediately they had found their man. Unbeknownst to them, Charleson had heard about the film from his father, and desperately wanted to play the part, feeling it would "fit like a kid glove".Ian McKellen, Hugh Hudson, Alan Bates, et al. ''For Ian Charleson: A Tribute''. London: Constable and Company, 1990. pp. xix, 9, 76. [[Ben Cross]], who plays Harold Abrahams, was discovered while playing Billy Flynn in ''[[Chicago (musical)|Chicago]]''. In addition to having a natural pugnaciousness, he had the desired ability to sing and play the piano.[http://www.bencross.net/biography.html Ben Cross – Bio on Official site] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091022043111/http://www.bencross.net/biography.html |date=22 October 2009 }} Cross was thrilled to be cast, and said he was moved to tears by the film's script.''Wings on Their Heels: The Making of'' Chariots of Fire. (2005 video; featurette on 2005 DVD). [[20th Century Fox]], which put up half of the production budget in exchange for distribution rights outside of North America,Chapman, pp. 273–274. insisted on having a couple of notable American names in the cast. Thus the small parts of the two American champion runners, Jackson Scholz and Charlie Paddock, were cast with recent headliners: [[Brad Davis (actor)|Brad Davis]] had recently starred in ''[[Midnight Express (film)|Midnight Express]]'' (also produced by Puttnam), and [[Dennis Christopher]] had recently starred, as a young bicycle racer, in the popular indie film ''[[Breaking Away]]''. All of the actors portraying runners underwent a gruelling three-month training intensive with renowned running coach Tom McNab. This training and isolation of the actors also created a strong bond and sense of camaraderie among them. === Music === {{Main|Chariots of Fire (album)}} [[File:Charleson on beach.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Ian Charleson]] (foreground) and [[Ben Cross]] (left) running in the "[[Chariots of Fire (instrumental)|Chariots of Fire]]" music scene which bookends the film.]] Although the film is a period piece, set in the 1920s, the [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]]-winning original soundtrack composed by [[Vangelis]] uses a modern 1980s electronic sound, with a strong use of [[synthesizer]] and piano among other instruments. This was a bold and significant departure from earlier period films, which employed sweeping orchestral instrumentals. The [[Chariots of Fire (instrumental)|title theme of the film]] has become iconic, and has been used in subsequent films and television shows during slow-motion segments. Vangelis, a Greek-born electronic composer who moved to Paris in the late 1960s, had been living in London since 1974.[http://vangeliscollector.com/telegraph112182.htm ''Daily Telegraph'' newspaper, 21 November 1982] Director Hugh Hudson had collaborated with him on documentaries and commercials, and was also particularly impressed with his 1979 albums ''[[Opera Sauvage]]'' and ''[[China (Vangelis album)|China]]''.MacNab, Geoffrey. [https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/features/everyone-was-a-winner-when-british-talent-met-the-olympic-spirit-7640574.html "Everyone Was a Winner when British Talent Met the Olympic Spirit"]. ''[[The Independent]]''. 13 April 2012. David Puttnam also greatly admired Vangelis's body of work, having originally selected his compositions for his previous film ''[[Midnight Express (film)|Midnight Express]]''.Hubbert, Julie. [https://books.google.com/books?id=gmc28iYGdMcC&pg=PA426&lpg=PA426&dq=puttnam+vangelis&source=bl&ots=uqcm-_PfON&sig=6frPR9-CwF_fxMfSjiVdlFwvKSI&hl=en&sa=X&ei=MkCJT9HJOqqciALJ2bDaCw&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=puttnam%20vangelis&f=false ''Celluloid Symphonies: Texts and Contexts in Film Music History'']. University of California Press, 2011. p. 426. Hudson made the choice for Vangelis and for a modern score: "I knew we needed a piece which was anachronistic to the period to give it a feel of modernity. It was a risky idea but we went with it rather than have a period symphonic score." The soundtrack had a personal significance to Vangelis: After composing the iconic theme tune he told Puttnam, "My father is a runner, and this is an anthem to him."McLaughlin, John. [https://archive.is/20130104210643/http://www.runnersworld.com/article/printer/1,7124,s6-243-297--14187-0,00.html "In Chariots They Ran"]. ''[[Runner's World]]''. February 2012. Hudson originally wanted Vangelis's 1977 tune "L'Enfant",[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3kRS4pkrBqE "L'Enfant", from ''Opera Sauvage''] from his ''Opera Sauvage'' album, to be the title theme of the film, and the beach running sequence was actually filmed with "L'Enfant" playing on loudspeakers for the runners to pace to. Vangelis finally convinced Hudson he could create a new and better piece for the film's main theme – and when he played the now-iconic "Chariots of Fire" theme for Hudson, it was agreed the new tune was unquestionably better.Vangelis in ''Chariots of Fire – The Reunion'' (2005 video; featurette on 2005 ''Chariots of Fire'' DVD) The "L'Enfant" melody still made it into the film: When the athletes reach Paris and enter the stadium, a brass band marches through the field, and first plays a modified, acoustic performance of the piece.[http://www.elsew.com/data/trivia.htm Trivia about Vangelis] Vangelis's electronic "L'Enfant" track eventually was used prominently in the 1982 film ''[[The Year of Living Dangerously (film)|The Year of Living Dangerously]]''. Some pieces of Vangelis's music in the film did not end up on the film's soundtrack album. One of them is the background music to the race Eric Liddell runs in the Scottish highlands. This piece is a version of "Hymne", the original version of which appears on Vangelis's 1979 album, ''[[Opéra sauvage]]''. Various versions are also included on Vangelis's compilation albums ''[[Themes (Vangelis album)|Themes]]'', ''[[Portraits (So Long Ago, So Clear)|Portraits]]'', and ''[[Odyssey: The Definitive Collection]]'', though none of these include the version used in the film. Five lively [[Gilbert and Sullivan]] tunes also appear in the soundtrack, and serve as jaunty period music which nicely counterpoints Vangelis's modern electronic score. These are: "He is an Englishman" from ''[[H.M.S. Pinafore]]'', "Three Little Maids from School Are We" from ''[[The Mikado]]'', "With Catlike Tread" from ''[[The Pirates of Penzance]]'', "The Soldiers of Our Queen" from ''[[Patience (opera)|Patience]]'', and "There Lived a King" from ''[[The Gondoliers]]''. The film also incorporates a major traditional work: "[[And did those feet in ancient time|Jerusalem]]", sung by a British choir at the 1978 funeral of Harold Abrahams. The words, written by William Blake in 1804-8, were set to music by Parry in 1916 as a celebration of England. This hymn has been described as "England's unofficial national anthem",Sanderson, Blair. [http://www.answers.com/topic/sir-charles-hubert-hastings-parry ''Hubert Parry''.] [[AllMusic]] Guide, reprinted in Answers.com. concludes the film and inspired its title.Manchel, Frank. [https://books.google.com/books?id=pSKLfQYNYDAC&pg=PA1013&dq=jerusalem+%22chariots+of+fire%22&hl=en&ei=KldJTLLrLpT4sAPQ1Z3wDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBjge#v=onepage&q=jerusalem%20%22chariots%20of%20fire%22&f=false ''Film Study: An Analytical Bibliography''.] Fairleigh Dickinson University Press, 1990. p. 1013 A handful of other traditional anthems and hymns and period-appropriate instrumental ballroom-dance music round out the film's soundtrack. ===Filming locations=== [[File:Chariots of Fire beach.jpg|thumb|left|250px|The beach running scene.]] The beach scenes associated with the theme tune were filmed at West Sands, [[St Andrews]]. A plaque commemorating the filming can be found there today. The very last scene of the opening titles crosses the 1st and 18th holes of the [[Old Course at St Andrews|Old Course]] at [[St Andrews Links]].[http://www.scotlandthemovie.com/movies/andrews.html ''Chariots of Fire'' – St Andrews] ''Scotland: The Movie Location Guide''[http://www.graylinescotland.com/tour.asp?tourid=46 Tours: St Andrews] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100614053333/http://www.graylinescotland.com/tour.asp?tourid=46 |date=14 June 2010 }} ''Gray Line Tours''. Describes Grannie Clark's Wynd, a public right-of-way over the 1st and the 18th of the Old Course, which was where the athletes were filmed running for the final titles shot. All of the Cambridge scenes were actually filmed at Hugh Hudson's alma mater [[Eton College]], because Cambridge refused filming rights, fearing depictions of anti-Semitism. The Cambridge administration greatly regretted the decision after the film's enormous success. [[Liverpool Town Hall]] was the setting for the scenes depicting the British Embassy in Paris. The [[Colombes]] [[Stade Olympique Yves-du-Manoir|Olympic Stadium]] in Paris was represented by the [[The Oval (Wirral)|Oval Sports Centre]], [[Bebington]], Merseyside.{{Cite journal|url=http://www.wheredidtheyfilmthat.co.uk/film.php?film_id=60|title=Chariots of Fire|publisher=Where Did They Film That?|accessdate=18 February 2007|postscript=}} The nearby [[Woodside, Merseyside|Woodside]] ferry terminal was used to represent the embarkation scenes set in [[Dover]]. The railway station scenes were filmed in York, using locomotives from the [[National Railway Museum]]. The scene depicting a performance of ''[[The Mikado]]'' was filmed in the [[Royal Court Theatre, Liverpool]] with members of the [[D'Oyly Carte Opera Company]] who were on tour.Bradley, Ian, ed.[https://books.google.com/books?id=pPj0nly_1OQC&pg=PA576&dq=%22savoy+theatre%22+%22chariots+of+fire%22&num=100#v=onepage&q=%22savoy%20theatre%22%20%22chariots%20of%20fire%22&f=false ''The Complete Annotated Gilbert and Sullivan.''] Oxford University Press, 2005. p. 576. ==Revival for the 2012 Olympics== ''Chariots of Fire'' became a recurring theme in promotions for the [[2012 Summer Olympics]] in London. The film's theme tune was featured at the opening of the 2012 London New Years fireworks celebrating the Olympics,[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q1yLRK2M8YQ London Fireworks 2012 - New Year Live - BBC One] and the film's iconic beach-running scene and theme tune were used in ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'''s "Let's Make It Great, Britain" Olympic ads.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H3b-o63wd_M "Let's Make It Great, Britain"] The runners who first tested the new [[Olympic Park, London|Olympic Park]] were spurred on by the ''Chariots of Fire'' theme tune,[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-17546859 "London 2012: Olympic Park Runners Finish Race"]. ''[[BBC News]]''. 31 March 2012. and the iconic music was also used to fanfare the carriers of the [[2012 Summer Olympics torch relay|Olympic flame]] on parts of its route through the UK.[http://www.northantset.co.uk/news/local/musicians-set-to-fanfare-the-flame-1-3693330 "Musicians Set to Fanfare the Flame"]. ''[[Northamptonshire Evening Telegraph]]''. 3 April 2012.[http://www.london2012.com/documents/marketing/line-the-steets-celebration-guide.pdf ''Line the Streets: Celebration Guide''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120424230303/http://www.london2012.com/documents/marketing/line-the-steets-celebration-guide.pdf |date=24 April 2012 }}. London 2012. p. 4. The beach-running sequence was also recreated at St. Andrews and filmed as part of the Olympic torch relay.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/torchrelay/day26|accessdate=20 March 2018|title=News: Torch Relay|publisher=BBC}} The film's theme was also performed by the [[London Symphony Orchestra]], conducted by [[Simon Rattle]], during the [[2012 Summer Olympics opening ceremony|Opening Ceremony]] of the games; the performance was accompanied by a comedy skit by [[Rowan Atkinson]] (as [[Mr Bean]]) which included the opening beach-running footage from the film.{{cite web|title=Mr. Bean's 'Chariots of Fire' Skit at 2012 London Olympics Opening Ceremony|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/367792/20120727/mr-bean-rowan-atkinson-olympic-opening-ceremony.htm|publisher=International Business Times|accessdate=29 July 2012}} The film's theme tune was also played during each medal ceremony of the 2012 Olympics. ===Stage adaptation=== {{main|Chariots of Fire (play)}} [[File:London26July2012d.jpg|290px|thumb|right|The ''[[Chariots of Fire (play)|Chariots of Fire]]'' stage adaptation: Stars [[Jack Lowden]] and [[James McArdle]] flank [[Vangelis]], watching the [[Olympic Torch Relay]] set to the iconic tune, from the [[Gielgud Theatre]], July 2012.]] A stage adaptation of ''Chariots of Fire'' was mounted in honour of the 2012 Olympics. The play, ''[[Chariots of Fire (play)|Chariots of Fire]]'', which was adapted by playwright [[Mike Bartlett (playwright)|Mike Bartlett]] and included the iconic Vangelis score, ran from 9 May to 16 June 2012 at London's [[Hampstead Theatre]], and transferred to the [[Gielgud Theatre]] in the [[West End theatre|West End]] on 23 June, where it ran until 5 January 2013.Rees, Jasper. [http://www.theartsdesk.com/film/chariots-fire-coming "''Chariots of Fire'' Is Coming!"] ''The Arts Desk''. 18 April 2012. It starred [[Jack Lowden]] as Eric Liddell and [[James McArdle]] as Harold Abrahams, and [[Edward Hall (director)|Edward Hall]] directed. Stage designer Miriam Buether transformed each theatre into an Olympic stadium, and composer Jason Carr wrote additional music.[http://westend.broadwayworld.com/article/Cast-Announced-for-Hampstead-Theatres-CHARIOTS-OF-FIRE-Opens-May-9-20120402# "Cast Announced for Hampstead Theatre's ''Chariots of Fire''; Opens May 9"]. ''Broadway World''. 2 April 2012.Girvan, Andrew. [http://www.whatsonstage.com/news/theatre/london/E8831331287794/Black+Watch's+Lowden+plays+Eric+Liddell+in+Chariots+of+Fire.html "''Black Watch'''s Lowden plays Eric Liddell in ''Chariots of Fire''"]. ''What's on Stage''. 9 March 2012.[http://www.hampsteadtheatre.com/page/3032/Chariots+of+Fire/302 ''Chariots of Fire'' – Hampstead Theatre] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120406044545/http://www.hampsteadtheatre.com/page/3032/Chariots%2Bof%2BFire/302 |date= 6 April 2012 }} Vangelis also created several new pieces of music for the production.Twitter: ''Chariots Tweeter'', [https://twitter.com/ChariotsHT/status/191903872313344000 16 April 2012], [https://twitter.com/ChariotsHT/status/192645441958055936 18 April 2012].Rees, Jasper. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/theatre-features/9241633/Chariots-of-Fire-The-British-are-coming...-again.html "''Chariots of Fire'': The British Are Coming... Again"]. ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''. 3 May 2012. The stage version for the London Olympic year was the idea of the film's director, Hugh Hudson, who co-produced the play; he stated, "Issues of faith, of refusal to compromise, standing up for one's beliefs, achieving something for the sake of it, with passion, and not just for fame or financial gain, are even more vital today."Jury, Louise. [https://archive.is/20120917112247/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-24032072-theatre-to-run-chariots-of-fire-with-vangelis-tracks.do "Theatre to Run ''Chariots of Fire'' with Vangelis Tracks"]. ''[[London Evening Standard]]''. 30 January 2012. Another play, ''Running for Glory'', written by Philip Dart, based on the 1924 Olympics, and focusing on Abrahams and Liddell, toured parts of Britain from 25 February to 1 April 2012. It starred Nicholas Jacobs as Harold Abrahams, and Tom Micklem as Eric Liddell.Elkin, Susan. [http://www.thestage.co.uk/listings/production.php/55936/running-for-glory "''Running for Glory''"]. ''[[The Stage]]''. 2 March 2012.[http://www.thisiskent.co.uk/Olympic-play-victory-stage/story-15189111-detail/story.html "Olympic Play Is Victory on Stage"] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130505124729/http://www.thisiskent.co.uk/Olympic-play-victory-stage/story-15189111-detail/story.html |date=5 May 2013 }}. ''This Is Kent''. 10 February 2012. ===UK cinematic re-release, Blu-ray=== As an official part of the London 2012 Festival celebrations, a new digitally re-mastered version of the film screened in 150 cinemas throughout the UK. The re-release began 13 July 2012, two weeks before the opening ceremony of the London Olympics.[http://www.bfi.org.uk/news/173 "''Chariots of Fire'' Returns to UK Cinemas Ahead of the Olympics"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120328130757/http://www.bfi.org.uk/news/173 |date=28 March 2012 }}. [[British Film Institute]]. 23 March 2012. A [[Blu-ray Disc|Blu-ray]] of the film was released on 10 July 2012 in North America,[https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00284AVN2 ''Chariots of Fire'' – Blu-ray] and was released 16 July 2012 in the UK.[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B007NFPN5M ''Chariots of Fire'' – 30th Anniversary Limited Edition Blu-ray] The release includes nearly an hour of special features, a CD sampler, and a 32-page "digibook".Sluss, Justin. [http://www.highdefdiscnews.com/?p=76109 "1981 Hugh Hudson Directed Film ''Chariots of Fire'' Comes to Blu-ray in July"]. HighDefDiscNews.com.[http://www.hometheaterforum.com/t/319681/whv-press-release-chariots-of-fire-blu-ray-book ''Chariots of Fire'' Blu-ray press release] ==Critical reception== Since its release ''Chariots of Fire'' has received generally positive reviews from critics. {{as of|2017}} the film holds an 83% "Certified Fresh" rating on review aggregator website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] based on 64 reviews, accompanied by the summary "Decidedly slower and less limber than the Olympic runners at the center of its story, the film nevertheless manages to make effectively stirring use of its spiritual and patriotic themes."[https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/chariots_of_fire]. Chariots of Fire (1981) - Rotten Tomatoes. Retrieved 3 January 2017. For its 2012 re-release, Kate Muir of ''[[The Times]]'' gave the film five stars, writing: "In a time when drug tests and synthetic fibres have replaced gumption and moral fibre, the tale of two runners competing against each other in the 1924 Olympics has a simple, undiminished power. From the opening scene of pale young men racing barefoot along the beach, full of hope and elation, backed by Vangelis's now famous anthem, the film is utterly compelling."[http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/arts/firstnightreviews/article3471497.ece]. "First Night Reviews: Chariots of Fire". Retrieved 3 January 2017. == Accolades == ''Chariots of Fire'' was very successful at the [[54th Academy Awards]], winning four of seven nominations. When accepting his Oscar for [[Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay|Best Original Screenplay]], [[Colin Welland]] famously announced "The British are coming".[https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2012/may/05/this-weeks-new-theatre-and-dance "This week's new theatre and dance"]. The Guardian. {{Refimprove|date=August 2008}}
'''Contraflow lane reversal''' is the altering of the normal flow of traffic, typically on a [[controlled-access]] highway (such as a freeway or motorway), to either aid in an [[emergency evacuation]] (the most common usage of the term in the [[United States]]) or, as part of [[Planned maintenance|routine maintenance]] activities, to facilitate widening or reconstruction of one of the highway's [[carriageway]]s (the most common usage in the [[United Kingdom]]).
Usually, the term is used to refer to reversal of lanes which are normally configured for travel in one direction; routinely changing the configuration of [[reversible lane#Entire roadway routinely reversed|reversible lanes]] (such as during [[rush hour]]) is not normally considered contraflow lane reversal.
==Emergency evacuation== In an emergency evacuation, contraflow lane reversal roughly doubles the number of lanes available for evacuation traffic. Crossover sections are used to move outgoing traffic to these lanes. All incoming traffic is blocked until the end of the evacuation.
Contraflow lane reversal is usually done on freeways and other controlled-access roadways; however, some examples listed below (particularly in [[South Carolina]]) are divided and undivided roadways. Use of contraflow lane reversal is generally considered to be an emergency measure, as the contraflow lanes (and any associated ramps at interchanges) lack proper [[traffic sign|signage]], [[traffic signal|signals]], and other traffic control devices needed to orderly conduct traffic in the opposite direction.
Generally, a significant number of police officers or other officials are needed to manually direct traffic during a lane reversal (especially at [[interchange (road)|interchanges]], where ramp traffic in the wrong direction must intersect with other roadways that are operating normally).
===Hurricane evacuation=== [[Image:Hurricane evacuation route marking.JPG|200px|thumb|right|Hurricane evacuation route marking near the Texas Gulf Coast]] From the 1990s, many states in the [[Southeastern United States]] adopted [[hurricane]] [[Hurricane evacuation route|evacuation routes]] from coastal areas using contraflow lane reversals on [[Interstate Highways]]. State highway departments have coordinated on plans for traffic direction with state [[highway patrol]] agencies, constructed highway median crossovers, and installed signage for drivers and barriers and swing arms to inhibit wrong-way collisions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.floridaits.com/Contraflow_Evac.htm |title=Contraflow Evacuation |publisher=Floridaits.com |date= |accessdate=2008-09-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080922105826/http://www.floridaits.com/Contraflow_Evac.htm |archivedate=2008-09-22 |df= }}</ref>
Most evacuation plans involve only a single state; however, the states of [[Louisiana]] and [[Mississippi]] have developed coordinated plans to evacuate the [[New Orleans metropolitan area]] by using [[Interstate 55]] and [[Interstate 59]].
Current contraflow evacuation plans exist for:
* [[Alabama]] ** [[Mobile, Alabama|Mobile]] via [[Interstate 65|I-65]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mcema.net/Evacuations-Procedures/Contraflow |title=Mobile County EMA > Evacuations Procedures > Contraflow |publisher=Mobile County Emergency Management Agency |date= |accessdate=2015-08-29}}</ref> [[File:Interstate 4 contraflow crossover at Interstate 75.jpg|thumb|Modular [[Jersey barriers]] are semi-permanently installed as a median barrier between the left and second-from-left bridges, along Interstate 4 near [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]]. They can be quickly removed to allow some eastbound traffic to transfer to the westbound lanes when contraflow is enacted.]] * [[Florida]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.floridaits.com/PDFs/TWO45_ContraFlow/050606-FIHS_Contraflow_Rprt-V1.pdf |title=Microsoft Word - 050605 TWO45 FIHS Contraflow Rprt V1-5 _redl PLH_.doc |date= |format=PDF |accessdate=2008-09-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080912203418/http://www.floridaits.com/PDFs/TWO45_ContraFlow/050606-FIHS_Contraflow_Rprt-V1.pdf |archivedate=2008-09-12 |df= }}</ref> (While the following contraflow plans exist, at the beginning of the 2017 hurricane season, Florida launched an [[Shoulder (road)#Emergency use by all traffic|emergency shoulder use scheme]] for hurricane evacuations along portions of I-4, I-10, & I-75.<ref>{{cite web|title=Emergency Shoulder Use (ESU)|url=http://fdot.gov/emergencymanagement/esu/|publisher=[[Florida Department of Transportation]]|accessdate=10 September 2017}}</ref><ref name="OS May 2017 shoulder-use plan">{{cite news|last1=Roustan|first1=Wayne|title=State introducing new hurricane evacuation plan this year|url=http://www.sun-sentinel.com/news/transportation/fl-hurricane-one-way-evacuations-20170518-story.html|accessdate=10 September 2017|work=[[Sun-Sentinel]]|date=26 May 2017}}</ref> It is not clear if the contraflow plans on these sections of highway will remain updated or will be scrapped.
